history.content:
Most of the work done in self-driving cars in the EECS department is under the umbrella of Berkeley DeepDrive - you could probably contact any of the people involved in it. In particular, Professor Bayen has been doing some very cool work on fleet driving and Professor Dragan did some work in the past on cars that plan based on human reactions. You could also take classes like CS280 if you're interested in some of the machine learning that goes into these technologies. Professor Tomlin also occasionally teaches a hybrid systems course that goes over the controls side of the area.

-----

Page 8 from Fearing's EE 192 lecture 1 is a good overview of what classes are most relevant to the field: https://inst.eecs.berkeley.edu/~ee192/sp18/files/lec1.pdf

To this list I would also add

-CS 287: the most directly relevant class to the field. Abbeel hasn't taught this in a while because robotics research has shifted more towards reinforcement learning so 294-112 has more or less taken it's place, but RL is not a reliable solution to most autonomous driving problems because of the safety costs involved

-CS 280: 3D Computer Vision is probably one of the biggest challenges in the field research wise

-CS 182: Deep learning has played a significant role in computer vision research as of late so it's hard to say it won't play a huge role in solving open vision problems

-ME 131 or EE 192, which provide the most direct experience for working with sensors, debugging robotics software, experiencing what it's like to put everything together. The former gives you more controls experience, the latter gives you more sensors/electronics experience, but there is large overlap.

-CS 294-115: incredibly relevant for behavioral and motion planning research

------------------

ME 231A teaches model predictive control, which is used in a lot of self-driving applications.

EECS C106A teaches ROS, in addition to a lot of robotics fundamentals, and many self driving companies use ROS for messaging

ME 233 teaches Kalman filtering, which is basically the standard solution for sensor fusion

Most of the work done in self-driving cars in the EECS department is under the umbrella of Berkeley DeepDrive - you could probably contact any of the people involved in it. In particular, Professor Bayen has been doing some very cool work on fleet driving and Professor Dragan did some work in the past on cars that plan based on human reactions. Professor Tomlin also occasionally teaches a hybrid systems course that goes over the controls side of the area.

I want to learn more about self driving cars and their potential future and costs. Are there any clubs on campus or professors with great knowledge on them?

I ask because I don't like driving, for many reasons, and am interested in a future in which I never(or for very short distances) have to drive myself and others.

Also, if anyone on this thread has opinions or information, please share. thank you.
history.subject: Self Driving Cars
